hints_html:
Remember that level curves satisfy \(f(x,y) = C\) where \(C\) is constant. Varying the value of \(C\) will give different level curves.

Don’t let the appearance of the exponential function trick into thinking this problem is more difficult than it is. Consider that if \(f(x,y) = C\), then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \ln(f(x,y)) = \ln(C)\end{aligned}\]

provided \(C > 0\).
hints_latex:
Remember that level curves satisfy $f(x,y) = C$ where $C$ is constant.
Varying the value of $C$ will give different level curves.

Don't let the appearance of the exponential function trick into thinking
this problem is more difficult than it is. Consider that if
$f(x,y) = C$, then

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \ln(f(x,y)) = \ln(C)
\end{align*} provided $C > 0$.
hints_raw:
Remember that <b>level curves</b> satisfy
<math>
f(x,y) = C
</math>
where <math>C</math> is constant. Varying the value of <math>C</math> will give different level curves.
Don't let the appearance of the exponential function trick into thinking this problem is more difficult than it is. Consider that if <math>f(x,y) = C</math>, then 
:<math>\displaystyle \ln(f(x,y)) = \ln(C)
</math>
provided <math>C > 0</math>.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The level curves of \(f(x,y)\) satisfy \(f(x,y) = C\) for arbitrary values of \(C\) such that a solution to \(f(x,y) = C\) exists. Starting with that equation we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^{-x^2 + 4y^2} = C.\end{aligned}\]

We notice that we can take the natural logarithm of both sides giving us

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -x^2 + 4y^2 = \ln(C),\end{aligned}\]

where \(\ln(C)\) is just an arbitrary constant as well! In other words, the level curves of \(e^{-x^2 + 4y^2}\) look the same as those of \(-x^2 + 4y^2 = g(x,y)\). The only difference between the level curves in each situation is the values of \(C\) corresponding to each specific curve. The level curves of \(g(x,y)\) are hyperbolae.

If we choose five different values of \(C\)

\[\begin{aligned} C = e^{-2}, e^{-1}, 1, e^{1}, e^{2}\end{aligned}\]

and draw the resulting level curves, we get the figure below. (Hint: If you begin drawing the level curves starting with \(C = 1\), the remaining curves should be easier to draw)
sols_latex:
The level curves of $f(x,y)$ satisfy $f(x,y) = C$ for arbitrary values
of $C$ such that a solution to $f(x,y) = C$ exists. Starting with that
equation we have

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
e^{-x^2 + 4y^2} = C.
\end{align*} We notice that we can take the natural logarithm
of both sides giving us

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-x^2 + 4y^2 = \ln(C),
\end{align*} where $\ln(C)$ is just an arbitrary constant as
well! In other words, the level curves of $e^{-x^2 + 4y^2}$ look the
same as those of $-x^2 + 4y^2 = g(x,y)$. The only difference between the
level curves in each situation is the values of $C$ corresponding to
each specific curve. The level curves of $g(x,y)$ are hyperbolae.

If we choose five different values of
$C$\begin{align*}
C = e^{-2}, e^{-1}, 1, e^{1}, e^{2}
\end{align*} and draw the resulting level
curves, we get the figure below. (Hint: If you begin drawing the level
curves starting with $C = 1$, the remaining curves should be easier to
draw)

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH200/December_2011/MATH200_Dec2011_Q1a_figure.png}
sols_raw:
The level curves of <math>f(x,y)</math> satisfy <math>f(x,y) = C</math> for arbitrary values of <math>C</math> such that a solution to <math>f(x,y) = C</math> exists. Starting with that equation we have
:<math>\displaystyle
e^{-x^2 + 4y^2} = C.
</math>
We notice that we can take the natural logarithm of both sides giving us
:<math>\displaystyle
-x^2 + 4y^2 = \ln(C),
</math>
where <math>\ln(C)</math> is just an arbitrary constant as well! In other words, the level curves of <math>e^{-x^2 + 4y^2}</math> look the same as those of <math>-x^2 + 4y^2 = g(x,y)</math>. The only difference between the level curves in each situation is the values of <math>C</math> corresponding to each specific curve. The level curves of <math>g(x,y)</math> are hyperbolae.

If we choose five different values of <math>C</math>: <math>C = e^{-2}, e^{-1}, 1, e^{1}, e^{2}</math> and draw the resulting level curves, we get the figure below. (<i>Hint: If you begin drawing the level curves starting with <math>C = 1</math>, the remaining curves should be easier to draw</i>)

[[File:MATH200 Dec2011 Q1a figure.png|center|frame|Some level curves of f(x,y)]]
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

a) Draw a “contour map” of \(f\), showing all types of level curves that occur.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>\displaystyle
f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}
</math>

a) Draw a "contour map" of <math>f</math>, showing all types of level curves that occur.
